body:
I have solved this issue, this issue arises because there is an exception which goes unhandled in case of localhost. [line](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/blob/master/mitmproxy/net/tcp.py#L294)
```
        if connection:
            self.connection = connection
            self.ip_address = connection.getpeername()
            self._makefile()
        else:
            self.connection = None

```

##### Solution :-
```
        if connection:
            try:
                self.connection = connection
                self.ip_address = connection.getpeername()
                self._makefile()
            except:
                self.ip_address = connection
                self._makefile()
        else:
            self.connection = None

```
##### System Information 
Mitmproxy: 3.0.0.dev1165 (commit 6dd336f) 
Python:    3.6.4
OpenSSL:   OpenSSL 1.1.0g  2 Nov 2017
Platform:  Linux-4.14.0-kali3-amd64-x86_64-with-Kali-kali-rolling-kali-rolling

@ankitsaini2609 

> Yes, their output is same I have checked it, getpeername() return the remote address to which the socket is connected. and in the case when exception happen value of connection is same as connection.getpeername()


so you mean `1234 == '1234'` would be same, cause `print(1234) and print('1234')` is same ?

Man , please check your basics first .

@ankitsaini2609 
Man, please don't delete your comments, if it's wrong we will correct you here.
I am working on it, give me some time yes I was wrong, let me modify my code little bit more

I was wrong before in which I was assigning  `self.ip_address = connection ` there is no need to assign `self.ip_address = connection` when you encounter that exception just pass that line and start execution from the next line, other exceptions will be handled by [line](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/blob/master/mitmproxy/net/tcp.py#L590)
##### Modified Code 
```
       if connection:
            try:
                self.connection = connection
                self.ip_address = connection.getpeername()
                self._makefile()
            except:
                self._makefile()

        else:
            self.connection = None
```
##### Image Attached 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20846432/35242288-2422a294-ffdf-11e7-8964-5026df4c1ba8.png)

@ankitsaini2609 
That was quick üòâ 
Need to test, on my system.
Can you send me the link of your branch where you have pushed your modified code, so that I can pull it and test it üëç 

Also, instead of only giving a reference like this 

It would be better if you give a small context and then the reference link. It lessens the pain of directly switching back and forth tabs. Something like this : 
[Referenced Code](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/blob/master/mitmproxy/net/tcp.py#L590)
```
 def connection_thread(self, connection, client_address):
        with self.handler_counter:
            try:
                self.handle_client_connection(connection, client_address)
            except:
                self.handle_error(connection, client_address)
            finally:
                close_socket(connection)
```
Actually, I am a noob but yeah I will remember it from next time.

@ankitsaini2609 
No worries man, we all are learning.
You learn a lot by getting involved with the community. Perhaps you have just started contributing in opensource projects.

**Follow community guidelines** , for starters don't delete your comments üòÉ
This is the [link](https://github.com/ankitsaini2609/mitmproxy/tree/issue2771) of my branch where I have pushed my modified code. :-)

issue.title: don't crash when being scanned with nmap locally, fix #2771

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body: I have solved issue #2771 kindly take a look :-)

body:
`nmap -sT localhost` currently causes mitmproxy to show this traceback:
```
~/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/net/tcp.py", line 296, in __init__
    self.ip_address = connection.getpeername()
OSError: [Errno 22] Invalid argument
```
However, nmap seems to successfully report that tcp/8080 is open (because of mitmproxy).

This is a race. Nmap connects to the socket, and immediately disconnects. We fire up the client connection thread, and attempt to retrieve the peer name from the connection. At this point the connection is closed, and we get OSError.
